awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bayesian Approaches for Inference on Brain Connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research project will develop new statistical methods for the analysis and interpretation of brain imaging data.  Statistical methods that improve signal detection and that lead to clinically relevant insights into the patterns of brain functions are needed.  This research will advance understanding of how the different regions of the brain interact and share information with each other during a task or at rest.  The statistical methods to be developed will have the potential to impact both statistics and neuroimaging and will apply generally to studies where multiple types of neuroimaging data are measured on groups of subjects. From a societal perspective, the acquired knowledge will guide clinicians in the selection of optimally targeted treatments to improve the quality of life of individuals. The project will include educational and training activities for graduate students. Findings will be disseminated to the research community and used to further interdisciplinary collaborative efforts in neuroimaging. Software and code will be developed and deposited in public repositories.

The new statistical methods to be developed will integrate the information provided by multiple imaging modalities collected on groups of subjects. A particular focus of the proposed research is to characterize the heterogeneity of brain functioning both within and between subjects. This research will produce flexible Bayesian statistical methods that can share information across subjects and take into account available knowledge on brain structure and functional mechanisms. New integrative spatio-temporal models will allow for the presence of highly connected and persistent hubs in the brain networks. Dynamic graphical model approaches will increase understanding of the dynamic nature of functional brain connectivity and how connectivity is disrupted when subjects are completing tasks. The investigators will apply the new methods to imaging data from subjects with a neurological disorder (epilepsy or schizophrenia) and data from healthy individuals who will serve as controls. Understanding the role that abnormalities in the brain connectome play in various neurological diseases has been a major focus in connectivity studies. Comparative analyses of data from healthy individuals serving as controls will allow the identification of differences in connectivity across groups of subjects and how they affect multiple cognitive domains.

por.por_cntn:
Brain connectivity aims to study how brain regions interact with each other to handle cognitive processes and to uncover how the brain works. Brain connectivity patterns may vary during the recording of a single neuroimaging experiment, across different experiments, and across subjects. The interaction among brain regions may also change because of neurological and mental health disorders. Under this award, we have proposed methods to characterize the heterogeneity of brain connectivity patterns typically observed in neuroimaging studies both within- and between- subjects. We have applied our methods to a study of temporal lobe epilepsy and to other neurological data.

To investigate how the brain connectivity patterns change across subjects in an fMRI study, we have proposed a statistical method that allows estimating how the observed signal in one brain region may predict the signal in other regions at a later time and improves inference by borrowing information among subjects that belong to the same group (e.g., disease patients and healthy controls, or patients with different disease subtypes). The method allows identifying the strongest connections while weeding out the noise. In addition, the resulting inference takes advantage of the available information about the physical connections in the brain by integrating the fMRI measurements with MRI-based measures of grey-matter volume or cortical thickness. We have applied our method to data from a study of temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE). We have demonstrated that patients with TLE exhibit several differences and similarities in effective connectivity compared to healthy controls. Since the method is computationally intensive, we then developed scalable implementations of the model by exploiting recent advances in machine learning and computational algorithms. We have applied our method on data from children with a history of traumatic injury and data from an animal study on memory.

Recent studies have outlined that brain connectivity may be dynamically changing and fluctuating within a subject also during a single fMRI scan, e.g., because the subject's mind wanders across several states in response to a task or simply due to the passing of time. To investigate the dynamic nature of the connectivity states experienced by a subject, we have proposed a modeling approach for the analysis of task-based fMRI studies that automatically identifies the change points in connectivity states from the data and assumes that the connectivity states may be related within a super-graph. We have applied our method to data from a sensory motor task fMRI dataset, revealing several interesting features, e.g., that brain regions related to executive control appeared involved both at rest and during the execution of a task, consistent with the pattern implied by the "wait-to-hear" design of the auditory stimulus. Finally, we have developed novel statistical methods to refine the ability of the model to identify new connectivity states over time.

During the project period, we have advised three Ph.D. students, who contributed substantially to the research and have successfully defended their doctoral thesis in Statistics either from Rice University or from the University of California, Irvine. We have also presented our research at national and international conferences, including ENAR, JSM, the ISI World Statistics Congress, CMStatistics, and the ISBA World Meeting. We have also presented three well-attended short courses on the analysis of fMRI data and brain connectivity at international conferences. Additional Ph.D. students have been involved in aspects of our research and appear as co-authors on all publications.

These projects demonstrate broader impacts, both in terms of the statistical models developed (which can be applied to scientific studies in the future) and the specific conclusions we have identified in our applications. We have developed well-documented code along with our methods. In particular, for our scalable implementation of the multi-subject brain connectivity project, we provide a user-friendly Matlab code available at https://github.com/rimehi/BVAR_connect. In terms of scientific conclusions, our study on TLE patients identified a central role of the so-called salience network, whose influence on the anterior default mode network was much lower in TLE patients than in healthy controls. Similarly, we identified significant differences between the connectivities in and out of the alerting network, which is postulated to be responsible for achieving and maintaining a state of readiness for incoming stimuli. Finally, all projects represent collaborations across multiple institutions.
